Hello Kelly. First of all, a very big
thank you for accepting to do
this little interview.

Thanks to you. Can you tell us
about yourself
and what you're working on? All right, yes. Thank you very much, Liliane. I am Kelly Picard, I am French,
a lecturer at the University Jean-Monnet, near Lyon, in public law.

I work more specifically in public law. I've been working
for about ten years now

on the notions of historical prejudice
and transitional justice. We will go back to this later.

Specifically, I dedicated
my PhD thesis to these questions, namely, the question of
the responsibility of the State

in the reparation
of historical damage. In addition,

my research mainly deals with the protection
of rights and freedoms,

mechanisms of justice and reparation
in post-conflict situations,

typically, Truth
and Reconciliation Commissions, and the different forms of reparation
considered in such contexts,

which somewhat fall
outside the typical legal framework. I also had the opportunity
to go into the field
in order to assess the theories that I had developed during my research,

particularly for the Central African context
in Bangui, in the Central African Republic,

where I was able to participate
in the process of reconstruction of the State,

or at least in the post-conflict period
in recent years. There it is.

Thank you. To get straight
to the core of this topic,

you said that you are working
on historical prejudice. Can you tell us exactly what it is,
what you mean by that?

Yes, of course. The first thing you need to know
about historical prejudice

is that it doesn't actually
exist legally. So this is already a first obstacle.

It doesn't exist, so it was
my concern to conceptualize it because even though legally,
it doesn't exist,

the social impacts
that can be experienced through historical prejudice
are very present

and therefore I found it necessary
to conceptualize the idea.

So, what do I mean
by historical prejudice? Broadly speaking,

it is the idea of a situation
of extreme violence,

whether it is extreme
in its gravity or in its mass character. Extreme violence
that has not found a response in terms of justice or reparation.

Therefore, over time, the State has not provided
a satisfactory

or sufficient response in terms of justice,
so justice in the broad sense, that includes precisely these questions
of reparation, truth, and so on.

This has created a feeling
of resentment, frustration,

anger, a certain form
of animosity, even mistrust, which is transmitted
from generation to generation

until it potentially explodes
like a sleeping bomb.

Françoise Sironi,
who is a psychologist, talks about the sleeping
bomb in society when we do not
take seriously

these phenomena of violence
which are very serious and which we prefer to dismiss,

to put under the carpet
in order to get rid of them, saying: "Let's move forward. The past is in the past, etc."

These social phenomena... So, my concern was to try to give
a concrete and legal reality

to this phenomenon and to try
to have it taken into account in court

so that we can finally
bring a response in terms of reparation and justice
to the people who were

in fact doubly victimized,
because they were victims at the time of the violence, victims of abuse,

typically everything that is
a crime against humanity, genocide, war crimes,
therefore serious violence.

Then, they are doubly
victimized by being denied
their status as victims

and never recognized as such, and when the State never
recognizes their suffering and the prejudices
they have experienced and suffered.

So, this reinforces once again
this feeling of injustice,

a double injustice both in the State
that has allowed the violence to take place,

and also in the State that has not
brought justice for this violence.

This is what I mean
by historical prejudice.

Thank you very much. Therefore, do the crimes
of colonization and the crimes of slavery

fit into this category
or since the crimes of slavery
have been considered as crimes
against humanity,

is it no longer necessary
to use this category?

So, I include the crimes
of colonization and slavery in this category
of historical prejudice

because there is indeed this double dimension
through historical prejudice. Why historical?

Because there is this double
phenomenon in terms of history. There is history in the sense
that there has been a punctual event,

a historical event
that has generated a prejudice. Then there are the historical facts
in time, diffuse, latent,

which create
this historical dimension. In this double meaning,
namely old prejudices

such as colonization or slavery, could fit
into this category.

Then, if we enter into purely legal
and technical questions,

we have the questions
of prescriptions, of the interest to act
which will come into question and will constitute obstacles
to legal actions.

Perhaps we will
come back to this later, but typically both colonization and slavery
constitute historical prejudices

to the extent that
they were characterized by extremely serious violence.

In the French case, for example, colonial
slavery or the Algerian war
did not receive a sufficient

or satisfactory response
in terms of justice. So we would typically
approach these situations.

To make sure we understand well, what do we actually gain by using
this category of historical prejudice

rather than crimes
against humanity? Good question.
The point is... Actually...

So I'm just thinking about it,
so I don't say anything foolish. The idea of historical prejudice,
which is also underlying,

is the idea of a prejudice
that is transgenerational.

This is a little bit
the idea that I defend and which is a little bit
complicated for lawyers

to conceive
in a very Cartesian mind. It is the idea that, in fact,
this violence, this phenomenon,

the war crime
or crime against humanity, did not only have
repercussions on the people

who were present
at the time of this violence, but it also had repercussions
on the descendants of these people,

the descendants
of these direct victims. There were phenomena... When we study
psychology or sociology,

or even now
neuroscience, there is more and more
research that tends to show

that there is
a transmission of trauma, sometimes even
in the genetic heritage

or in the psychological heritage. There really is a form
of transmission of traumas,

injustices,
repercussions over time. Therefore, the idea also through...

The idea of historical prejudices
would be to recognize also the potential effects
on all the successive generations
and to understand better, the society as it is today

tend to be taken into account
and considered a little more.

Some lawyers
before the International Criminal Court

of transgenerational harm,

because it is specifically in the Katanga case - if I'm not wrong- concerning
the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The Court agreed
to recognize... So it was a question
of crimes against humanity, war crimes.

The Court agreed
to recognize transgenerational harm. So the fact that the descendants,
the children of people

who experienced these wars, these attacks,
these events have suffered damage, psychological consequences,
sometimes physical consequences.

We could elaborate,
but there is also a whole...

The field of study that I also like
in these questions is the case of Rwanda, because in fact,
the effects of war rapes,
at least on future generations,

are particularly evocative
because women have contracted diseases,

women who have given birth to children
as a result of these rapes. Thus, the effects
on the generations to come

are particularly serious
and striking. We can observe them very well.

The fact remains, and I return
to the International Criminal Court, it recognized these prejudices.

It did not deny them,
it recognized them, but refused to repair them.

It was considered
that the causal link couldn't be proved.

It was difficult to really
prove that the pathologies
that young children suffer today, the psychological disorders, and so on,

were directly
and certainly attributable to the fact that their parents
had suffered this violence.

So, it is the causal link that was somewhat lacking, but we are making progress,
step by step.

So, just to answer your question
in one sentence, because I took a few
detours, the difference

with crime against humanity
is that for crimes against humanity we only take into consideration
the direct victims,

therefore, the first rank of victims
who are concerned by this violence. The idea would be
to see the global picture

and all the repercussions
on society, because massive violence
such as war

and crimes against humanity
do not only have repercussions on the people who
have experienced these phenomena.
In my opinion, it has repercussions and disruptions, like a big ripple effect.

There is not one person

There is this idea

Well, it's not that

It is not possible to engage

In fact, there is the idea of intention. To hold, for example, accountable an individual

it is necessary to prove
before a judge that this individual had the intention
to exterminate a population.

Now, in fact, this contradicts
the principle of a State, since it is not a person
who is thinking as such,

so one cannot prove
the intention of a State legally, even tough one could question it.

However, in the current context,

Therefore, these are public responsibilities.

Thus, public means
the whole State community, all the State institutions.

The criminal liability

the State always

Okay. I don't want to make

At this point, therefore,
it is possible, indeed, to activate
the responsibility of the State, both internally, nationally,

Both cases or possible. On the internal level,

for faults or without fault.

Both are possible. So if it is for a fault, there is

So, it's a little bit limited

However,
there are possibilities. It should be noted that earlier
I was talking about the ICC,

the International Criminal Court. This is a court that is

So, not States, but individuals

So, if we were to prosecute
the colonial crimes of France,

what would be possible? I mean, I guess
it depends a little bit

on where the crimes

at the national,

we have several options

I am an optimist

at the international level,

we don't have
many levers of action because
we may have

it is quite possible.
Moreover, there is at the moment, and the decision will be announced soon.

An action before
the European Court of Human Rights concerning the reparation
of French colonial slavery.

On the basis of this famous law,
the Taubira law of 2001, which recognizes colonial slavery
as a crime against humanity.

It is actually a group, the Mouvement International pour les Réparations

legal actions in France

to demand reparations
because, in fact, they have underlined the fact that a penal qualification
has been established,

that it has been recognized
that there was a crime against humanity, but that this has not been accompanied
by any reparations, which is peculiar because it has been
established that there is a crime,

but no repairs have been made. Thus, they took
legal action before the French courts. Each time, they have been rejected
and so they have reached

the European Court
of Human Rights, where they are trying
to defend their case.

We will see what the Court will say,
even if, well, generally, it is not very daring

on this kind of sensitive issue. However, it could be a way
to try to get some leverage,

to put some diplomatic
pressure on. Therefore, we'll see
what happens.

We need to point out
another issue. It is the temporal competence
of these courts.

In fact, all these
international jurisdictions are quite recent

and, for example,
the European Court of Human Rights, France only ratified the statute,
so it only accepted

the jurisdiction
of the Court in 1974. This means that everything
that happened before 1974,

cannot be considered by the Court. If we take the case of the ICC,
the International Criminal Court,

came into force in 2002. The same thing applies
to all the facts prior to 2002,

which the Court
cannot determine. Therefore, we have
a real problem with the question
of the Algerian war.

It happened a long time ago, and thus, the competence
of the courts is limited.

Hence my bias, I actually
try to go through the back door
of transgenerational prejudices

and to recognize the fact that,
even if the facts are old, the repercussions
on individuals

are still present and these actions
still have consequences.

Therefore, there are still prejudices
today that are suffered, but it is a little difficult
to get the courts to recognize it.

There is this barrier,
that is temporal, which means that
there is no way around it.

There is no retroactive application. A court cannot take up
facts that took place before it was created.

That is a real problem. On the other hand,
there is the possibility of creating

institutions that are
somewhat specialized, like we did, for example, for the International Criminal Tribunal
for the former Yugoslavia

or for Rwanda,
creating specific jurisdictions that will deal with past events,

but they will be created for this purpose,

At the national level, there is still the possibility
of referring to the domestic courts.

We are also left with a somewhat
Franco-French question.

Finally, there is not this... Although there is not

of cooperation

the current debates. We approach the subject
a little from our French perspective.

However, it can be a way to move things forward
in terms of reparation.
The difficulty is to find the right legal basis,

to justify the prejudice
and the causal link. In fact, for liability,
three things must be demonstrated.

You have to show
a causal event. You have to show a prejudice

and a causal link
between the event and the prejudice
and often the difficult part

it is to show the 100 %
causality between the two.

That's where
the courts rush in to dismiss this type of litigation

and once again,
sweep it under the carpet. So, if I understand you
correctly,

the alternative would be
to try to mobilize as much as possible this category
of historical prejudice.

That would be the alternative? Well, yes,
but I'm preaching

to my choir here,
but of course that's how I approached it.

After that, there is
everything that is... In fact, when I worked
on these questions for my thesis,

I was quickly confronted... I considered
all the possible mechanisms of responsibility.

I saw that even if each time, there is a small step missing
to be able to get there, these are obstacles
and as I said,

well the lawyers, they are straightforward,
Cartesian, so all these things and the fact that
there are repercussions

on the bodies and the minds
of the generations after, it is something that is
going to take a little bit of time to process.

So, there is another possibility, which is not to resort
to the legal route at all,

that is to say that we must
ask ourselves the question : what do we want?

If what we want is
a form of reparation, but that maybe translates
into official public recognition, into public policies,

whatever they may be, whether it is a bit
of positive discrimination,

whether it is access
to care, whether it is compensation.

In reality, you don't necessarily need
to use the legal system, and that is why I looked into

transitional justice,
because it actually is the essence of transitional justice.

It is a justice that faced
with the obstacles of its environment

and the rigidity of the law,
will work around it, use various ways and set up

paralegal systems
that borrow a little bit from the ceremonial of justice,
but that fit next to

and in parallel
with institutional justice. Hence, typically,
the Truth and Reconciliation Commissions,

like those made
in South Africa or elsewhere. There is also an option
that is quite interesting to explore,

and which is starting
to come up quite a bit, which is what we call
courts of opinion.

Tribunals of opinion
have been set up, for example, in the field of environmental law.

The Monsanto tribunal is
actually a court of opinion. So, given that
environmental law was not

sufficiently developed,
we still do not have a consensus on the crime of ecocide,
and so on,

well, a simulation
of the tribunal is made. We recreate all the ceremonial
of a court with experts,
public figures, and we pretend to judge the facts in question.

This was also done

these Korean women

Faced with the reluctance

they set up

either borrowing
